text: Cat jumps on imam leading Ramadan prayers in Algeria. Imam Walid Mehsas was praying Taraweeh, a nightly prayer occurring every evening during the month of Ramadan, when the cat jumped on him and climbed on his shoulders.

Why is it important to some in Lesotho to claim back land from South Africa? Pastor Kenneth Matee, spokesperson for the Basotho Covenant Movement, explains

Leading Senegalese opposition leader Ousmane Sonko has been found guilty of libel and handed a two-month suspended jail sentence. Sonko was charged with libel after accusing the country's Tourism Minister of embezzlement. More here: https://bbc.in/3G6zVu4

A South African parole board is to consider whether former Paralympics star Oscar Pistorius can be released from jail. He has so far served half of his 13-year sentence for murdering his girlfriend Reeva Steenkamp in 2013.

Komba Johnbul used to spend his days digging in the mud. Then, six years ago, he found a huge 709 carat diamond. It’s what miners like him dream of, but ‘striking gold’ wasn't everything he expected it to be. Listen to his story on #TheComb: https://bbc.in/3JW0e7l BBC/Getty

Fasting at any time can be a risk for people with diabetes, so for observers of Ramadan who also have the condition, taking part in fasting can cause concern. Kenyan diabetes care specialist, Dr Hilda Nabiswa, has advice on how diabetics can keep safe.
French court has handed a four-year jail term to a Rwandan for starting a fire that severely damaged a Gothic cathedral in the western French city of Nantes in 2020. More here: https://bbc.in/3LZ1ola
Malawi's to declare 537 missing persons dead following Storm Freddy. The tropical storm saw mudslides sweep through neighbourhoods and bury people in mud. More here: https://bbc.in/3M42lIR

In November 2020, a #BBCAfricaEye investigation revealed that Crowd1 is peddling a range of bogus products and false promises to cover an old-fashioned pyramid scheme based on recruitment: https://bbc.in/3p582JX

The #Crowd1 scheme appears to have made a fortune for a handful of European scammers - many of them Swedish - but it has left behind a trail of debt and poverty in countries including #SouthAfrica and #Nigeria. #BBCAfricaEye's story

“This rising dictatorship is something we’re not really comfortable with.” The governor of Kenya’s Kisumu County, Peter Anyang Nyong’o, tells @BBC_AudreyB why he has been at the forefront of protests against the Ruto government.

False and misleading social media videos about migrants from sub-Saharan Africa have been widely circulated in Tunisia, amid a wave of anti-migrant sentiment. The BBC's been investigating the videos... Watch Read https://bbc.in/3FWwWEq

Pilots failed to take notice and respond to warning systems before a plane crashed in Tanzania, according to an investigation report. 19 people died when the plane crashed into Lake Victoria in November. More here: https://bbc.in/3K66n1S

text: You can now go to jail for life in Uganda, just by identifying as gay according to a new anti-LGBT bill. Homosexual acts are already illegal in Uganda but this bill introduces many new criminal offences.

The legalisation of cannabis farming in Malawi inspired many farmers to start growing the plant with hopes of high returns. But that hope has dimmed, as farmers like Ethel have still not been able to grow a single cannabis plant after years of waiting.

Would you put your career on hold to focus on reviving traditional belief systems and practices? Kenyan Wairimu Mukuru did just that, and celebrates her Kikuyu roots through teaching and sharing TikTok videos.
A South African choir, known as the African Native Choir, performed for Queen Victoria in the late 1800’s. See their remarkable story through pictures here.
The government of Ethiopia has rejected claims by the US that allege members of its forces committed war crimes during the two-year war in Tigray. https://bbc.in/3n6IwGC

Is a close Russia-Africa relationship on the horizon? Vladimir Putin says he will prioritise relations with African countries as he looks for international partners, in light of Russia facing Western sanctions over the invasion of Ukraine. https://bbc.in/3Z2cmcj

Despite facing a police ban, Namibian activists have vowed to protest on the day that marks the country’s 33 years of independence. The activists are protesting against high unemployment rates and alleged “looting and mismanagement of the country”. https://bbc.in/3JUDzcE

Facebook content moderators in Kenya are suing Meta for unfair dismissal. The moderators say they lost their jobs with Sama, a Kenya-based firm contracted to moderate Facebook content, for organising a union. More here: https://bbc.in/42Ei47w
A South African choir, known as the African Native Choir, performed for Queen Victoria in the late 1800’s. See their remarkable story through pictures here.

Senegal’s opposition leader Ousmane Sonko says he’s survived an attack on his “physical safety”. He’s accusing President Macky Sall of leading a “strategy of terror” in order to drive out political opponents in the country. https://bbc.in/3JAsPir

Around 43,000 people may have died last year because of the drought in Somalia, according to the first official death toll released by the UN. Half of the victims are thought to be children under five.

One problem has been getting aid into territory controlled by armed militants from al-Shabab. Millions of farm animals have died in the crisis, which has been worsened by climate change, political instability, and the global rise in food price.
Read more here:

A US aid worker and French journalist who had been kidnapped by militants in West Africa have been released. Jeffery Woodke went missing in 2016 and Olivier Dubois had been held hostage for almost two years.

Is a close Russia-Africa relationship on the horizon? Vladimir Putin says he will prioritise relations with African countries as he looks for international partners, in light of Russia facing Western sanctions over the invasion of Ukraine. https://bbc.in/3LzTwq5

Right to protest “does not give anyone the right to harass, intimidate or threaten.” South African President Cyril Ramaphosa has spoken out in light of the protests taking place in his country against his alleged economic mismanagement. https://bbc.in/3JC01Gq

One person has been shot in the middle of protests led by Kenya’s main opposition party. The BBC's @FerdyOmondi reports that traders are screaming that he is a mechanic, not a protester. They say it's a police officer who fired at him. https://bbc.in/3FCKk0p

Kenyan police are using water canons and tear gas to disperse protesters in the capital Nairobi. Planned by opposition leader Raila Odinga, the protests are taking place to address the high cost of living and the outcome of the last general election. https://bbc.in/3n4gqM5

Violet’s daughter-in-law fell victim to the unforgiving power of a landslide in Malawi. And despite the devastation caused by Tropical Storm Freddy, she is still holding out for hope that her daughter-in-law will be found alive.

A South African accountant who was investigating high-level corruption cases has been shot dead along with his son. Cloete Murray was the liquidator for a company implicated in numerous government contract scandals.
A group of artists have painted murals in Kenya's capital, Nairobi, in solidarity with Ukraine amid the ongoing invasion by Russia. : https://bbc.in/3yIuD3U

An American couple has been charged in Uganda with the torture and trafficking of a 10-year-old boy. The magistrate says there’s enough evidence for a trial for the couple, who have been held in a maximum security prison for the last three months. https://bbc.in/3n2vbPi

A court in Zimbabwe has refused to dismiss a charge of incitement against opposition lawmaker Job Sikhala. He was charged for allegedly inciting riots that erupted when opposition supporters clashed with Zanu-PF supporters. More here: https://bbc.in/3lhwsSm

26-year-old Rukayat Shittu has won a seat in the Kwara state house of assembly election in Nigeria. She will be representing the Owode/Onire region. #NigeriaElection2023

\\"\"I'm so glad you're safe here\"\". That’s what King Charles III had to say to former refugees who escaped by boat to Europe from the Darfur genocide. Sudanese activist Amouna Adam invited him to meet her community when they met on Holocaust Memorial Day.\""

Imagine paying $115 for a prayer - then going into debt for it. That’s Evarline’s story. She’s lives in Kibera, a slum in Kenya - and got into debt for prayers from a pastor. This practice is known as a ‘seed offering’ - what do you think of it?

“If I tell my mum that I'm making 'Ofe Owerri’ her reaction would be: ‘Who is coming over?’” @DishesByQ tells us why Nigeria's Ofe Owerri soup should *always* be made for someone special. : @SarahTiamiyu

After she fell pregnant, Esnath was forced to drop out due to a policy that banned pregnant girls from going to school. That was before President Samia Suluhu Hassan overturned the policy in 2021. Now, girls and mothers can freely resume their education in Tanzania.

Dozens of Burkina Faso nationals have made their way back home after being repatriated in the wake of racist remarks made by Tunisia’s president. President Saeid said the migrants were part of a conspiracy to change the country’s demographic composition. https://bbc.in/3YSxXEd

“The more money you have, the more of a man you are.” How involved should fathers be in raising their children? We spoke to three fathers in South Africa to get their take. Listen here: https://bbc.in/3LKqc0j

Fighting has continued in eastern DR Congo despite a peace deal with M23 rebels. The DR Congo government spokesperson @PatrickMuyaya warns that it's in the interests of some people to see continued instability in the mineral-rich country.

text: Meet the Kenyan fashion designer who’s hoping to get her luxury handbags on the Oscars red carpet. A partnership between the Kenyan government and an Oscars gifting suite company last year led to her creations being featured.

Malawi has recorded 85 deaths in the city of Blantyre as a result of the devastating effects of Tropical Storm Freddy. Heavy rains and strong winds have destroyed houses in a country that was overwhelmed by the wrath of the natural disaster. https://bbc.in/407GKDo

There’s no evidence of wrong doing by President Cyril Ramaphosa concerning the theft of $580,000 from his farm, that’s according to South Africa’s anti-corruption watchdog. More here: https://bbc.in/3Td648C
Namibia’s president wants a woman to succeed him. President Hage Geingob named Netumbo Nandi-Ndaitwah as the sole candidate for the ruling Swapo party in next year's elections. https://bbc.in/3la3lAc
How might African start-ups be affected by the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank? #FocusOnAfrica spoke to @Benji_Fernandes who founded Tanzanian fintech NALA, which formerly banked with SVB.

Mozambicans are bracing themselves for more havoc as cyclone #Freddy bears down on the country for the second time in three weeks. Disaster risk co-ordinator @Egidio_E_Joao tells #FocusOnAfrica how local residents are preparing to keep themselves safe.

Did you know that one of football’s biggest stars Pele once visited Nigeria? In 1969, with a civil war raging, the Brazilian sportsman arrived in Benin City as part of a visit that would change Nigerian football forever.

More than 2.7 billion people around the world are without regular internet access. In most African countries, women have less access than men. So, what can be done to help level the playing field? #IWD #EmbraceEquity Listen here: https://bbc.in/3ysVS2d

Kenya is cracking down on the ‘infiltration of LGBT agenda’ in schools. There are fears the programme could see misinformation about LGBTQ people and same-sex relationships taught in schools. More here: https://bbc.in/3La1kOX

text: President Cyril Ramaphosa has expressed concern about the wage strike by public workers that is affecting essential services in the country. The workers are demanding a 10% pay hike after rejecting the government's 3% increase. More here: https://bbc.in/41YR6Hg

There’s a brutal storm that’s ruining people’s homes and livelihoods in southern Africa. Cyclone Freddy has claimed the lives of 21 people and may become the longest-lasting storm on record as it's been spinning over the Indian Ocean for 32 days. THREAD

So what’s the situation in Mozambique? Mozambique is now bracing for a second landfall, whilst still reeling from the rains and floods brought by the storm. More than 160,000 people have already been affected by Freddy, according to the @WFP .
As for Madagascar, it’s received round three times its usual monthly average rainfall in the past week alone. The BBC's @annesoy has more on #CycloneFreddy

South Sudanese President Salva Kiir has sacked his foreign minister, just less than a week after sacking the defence and interior ministers. No explanation has been given for the dismissal of Mayiik Ayii Deng. https://bbc.in/3JqG0DH

Lesline lost her leg in a car accident when she was two years-old. She's now part of the Women’s Amputee Football Association of Cameroon, which is making a huge impact on the lives of women coping with the loss of a limb #InternationalWomensDay | #embraceequity2023

This crowdfund campaign raised more than $1.6m within 48 hours. Backed by Ethiopian comedian Eshetu Melese, the fund is for a charity that plans to build what it describes as the first nursing home facility for homeless people in the country. https://bbc.in/3T3ntjR
For the first time ever in Tanzania's history, President Samia Suluhu has attended an International Women's Day event organised by Chadema, the main opposition party. https://bbc.in/3l7RceW

Didier Drogba wants better medical checks to be given to footballers in his native Ivory Coast. This comes after the sudden death of RCA player, Moustapha Sylla, who collapsed during a football match.

Nigeria’s upcoming election for state governors and local assemblies has been postponed by one week. The polls, which had been scheduled to take place on Saturday, will now be held on 18 March. #NigeriaElections2023 #2023elections https://bbc.in/3J5BYzi
Nigerian filmmaker @FieryCJ , talks to #AfricaDaily podcast about his film Mami Wata, and making it to Africa's biggest film and television festival, FESPACO. Listen here: https://bbc.in/3ZGBV3A
The UN Secretary General Antonio Guterres has urged M23 rebels in DR Congo to respect a ceasefire agreement set to come into effect on Tuesday. https://bbc.in/3SSLsCg

President Emmanuel Macron has finished his 18th presidential trip in Africa at a time of rising competition from China and Russia. Macron is trying to shift French policy away from military involvement amid growing resentment against France in Africa.

Twenty five percent of women and girls across the world suffer from malnutrition during pregnancy - and the numbers have soared in the last two years. The world's poorest regions, such as Somalia, Ethiopia and Afghanistan, have been most affected.

A statue with a smiley face and dimples has been unearthed in Egypt. Archeologists also found the remains of a shrine in an ancient temple in southern Egypt. The artefacts were found near the Hathor Temple, one of Egypt's best-preserved ancient sites.

Meet the Rwandan referee who made football history Rwanda’s Salima Mukansanga made headlines around the world at the end of 2022 when she became one of the first female referees to be selected for the men’s World Cup. #IWD2023 #EmbraceEquity #InternationalWomensDay2023

It was the first time in the competition’s 92 years that women were also on the pitch, paving the way for aspiring female officials. The 34-year-old was also the first woman to take charge of a match at the men’s Africa Cup of Nations in Cameroon. #IWD2023 #EmbraceEquity

A true trailblazer, Mukansanga’s achievements are monumental and her impact will continue to be felt, far and wide, inspiring women and girls to break boundaries and sporting rules. #InternationalWomensDay2023 #IWD2023 #EmbraceEquity

Daniel found himself stranded in Antigua after fleeing war back home in Cameroon. He is a victim of a people-smuggling operation that has landed more than 600 Cameroonians on the Caribbean island, with the hope that they’d make it to the USA.

The head of the World Bank says Tunisia’s President Kais Saied’s comments triggered racially motivated violence. The organisation has suspended talks over its future engagement with Tunisia following Mr Saied's recent criticism of sub-Saharan migrants. https://bbc.in/3L65W8P

In a bid to address its power shortage issues, South Africa has appointed the country’s first electricity minister. Kgosientsho Ramokgopa's most important task will be to end the daily blackouts, which can last up to 15 hours a day.
